title: Why does Frozen Heart not have a visual aura?
body: Why does this bad boy not have a visual aura? {{item:3001}} has one. How cool would it be to have a frozen circle following you around like {{champion:44}} ? Just another clarity thing.

replies.body:
The reason we don't have one is actually for the sake of clarity. While adding more effects, indicators, etc can result in improved clarity there is a cost to doing so which is increasing visual noise. There is only so much screen space and so many places, objects, and moving pieces a single players eyes can follow and interpret in a given scenario. Once you hit that threshold any additional effects or indicators either get lost or visually clobber another important gameplay effect. It can be as helpful, if not more helpful, to remove or reduce the size of existing effects in improve clarity rather than add or amplify existing effects. 

In this specific case a giant frozen circle ring would almost certainly cause more clutter and obfuscate more desired effects than improve overall clarity. Though it would feel pretty cool for the purchaser (which is important) the clarity cost by adding that much visual noise was high enough we chose not to do it.

What if I proposed a small haze-like visual similar to Hecarim's Spirit of Dread? EDIT: I meant to add that it's not the same size as Hec's W; I was thinking about a 200 unit distance for the visual...although I know with that, the haze might be misleading to the aura's actual range.

Okay, stop with the bullshit buzzwords. You've added a ridiculous amount of effect clutter to the game over time; FH's power is certainly worth highlighting considering the team-wide %AS effect it has, which *nobody* gives enough weight to. Unless you specifically remember who has the aura and can eyeball the radius effect by memory, you can't make decisions around that aura, and -15% AS is hardly an insignificant effect.

Nobody wants fifty rings overlapping because you guys shove too many passive auras in the game, but FH should at least have a noticeable indicator effect. You want to play the buzzword game? Hey, look, I have another one! Let's take "invisible power" for a spin: that's another term which devs like to use with incredibly selective memory.
